5083015.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
5083015.theme: Climate change,Rural services and infrastructure,Technology diffusion,Other financial and private sector development,Infrastructure services for private sector development
5083015.trustfund:
TF029633-PHRD-SOLAR HOMES SYSTEMS (SHS) PROJ.,TF022865-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY POLICY &
            PROJECT DEV.,TF024995-USTDA-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT,TF023485-USDOE-ALTERNATIVE ENERGY ACTIVITIES,TF032882-INDONESIA - POWER,TF031934-INDONESIA - POWER, RENEWABLE ENERGY
5083015.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Despite an unsatisfactory project
            outcome assessment - due to factors outside government
            control, such as the banking sector crisis, market collapse,
            depreciation, and reduced business affordability -
            sustainability is likely due to considerable capacity
            building, increased demand for solar home systems (SHS), and
            commercial banking support. Furthermore, institutional
            development impacts are high, while the proactive actions by
            the project team, superior project supervision, and, the
            Government's collaborative approach to project
            preparation deemed highly satisfactory, and satisfactory
            performance ratings for the Bank, and Borrower,
            respectively. Lessons underline that market-based projects
            should provide broad scope for companies to adjust product
            lines, and business models, to meet changing market signals,
            while significant market entry support for firms, as well as
            performance based grants that scale down over time, are
            necessary. Nonetheless, the convincing end-user audit
            program, and transparent grant releases, encouraged dealers
            to participate in the project, and follow the consumer
            protection requirements, encouraging participating dealers
            to learn and market efforts on rural consumers.
            Consequently, upstream, and monitoring support to financial
            organizations is necessary to increase sector knowledge,
            given that the high costs of market entry that confront
            dealers, are mirrored by the costs confronted by
            organizations that would finance them. Hence, dealer
            performance information, may reduce transaction costs of
            financial institutions, and partially lower barriers to
            financing SHS dealers, and, a cross sectoral approach
            focused on both the consumer, and institutional photovoltaic
            markets, provides greater potential for sustained
            development impacts.

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal national objectives of the
            Solar Home Systems (SHS) Project are: (1) to provide the
            modern form of electricity to rural customers who cannot be
            served economically or in a timely manner by conventional
            rural electrification; (2) to facilitate private sector
            participation in advancing renewable energy
            commercialization; (3) to promote environmentally sound
            energy resource development in Indonesia and reduce the
            energy sector's dependence on fossil fuels; and (4) to
            strengthen Indonesia's institutional capacity to
            support and sustain decentralized rural electrification
            using solar photovoltaics. The project's global
            environmental objective is to mitigate carbon dioxide
            emissions in Indonesia.  The penetration of SHS will reduce
            these emissions by displacing the use of fossil fuels. The
            project consists of two major components: (1) a credit
            component comprising an IBRD loan and a GEF grant, to enable
            purchase of solar home systems by rural households and
            commercial establishments on an installment plan basis; and
            (2) technical assistance, including support of detailed
            monitoring and evaluation activities during project implementation.
